questions.text: Marriage and mortality belong under?
Number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group in a year refers to:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D) General fertility rate

 

General Fertility rate

Definition

The total number of live births in an area in a year per 1000 women in the

reproductive age group (15- 44 or 49 years).

Disadvantages and advantages

Disadvantage:

Not everyone in the reproductive age group is exposed to the risk of childbirth

questions.text: Which of the following fertility indicator can change with changes in age-specific mortality rates?
questions.explanation:
Net reproductive rate (NRR)

Definition

NRR is the number of daughters or girls a newborn will bear or have throughout her reproductive lifespan, considering the current age-specific fertility patterns and mortality rates.

Interpretation

  • It is the most sensitive indicator to evaluate National family planning program
  • It is a mortality-dependent fertility indicator. (Option D)
  • It is the best measure of growth of a population.

questions.text: What is the formula of crude birth rate?

options.label: A
options.text: (Total number of births / Estimated midyear Population) 1,000

options.label: B
options.text: (Number of live births / Estimated midyear women Population) 1,000

options.label: C
options.text: (Number of live births/ Estimated midyear Population) 1,000

options.label: D
options.text: (Number of live births / Estimated midyear Population) 1,0000

questions.correct_answer: C. (Number of live births/ Estimated midyear Population) 1,000
questions.explanation:
Crude birth rates

Definition

Number of live births per 1000 estimated

mid-year population in a given year.

Formula

Statistics

India’s current CBR is 19.5/1000 mid-year population. (2020)

Drawbacks

It gives a rough measure of fertility by giving birth rates, and not everyone in the population is exposed to childbirth.

questions.text: When is the population evaluated to calculate the crude death rate?
Which of the following indicators is not included in the Global Hunger Index (GHI) ?

options.label: D
options.text: Percentage of undernourished children under 5 years

questions.text: For a population of 10,000, what does a sex ratio of more than 1000 mean?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Males are less than 5000

References:

  • ↳ Importance in Demography : Crucial for understanding population dynamics.
  • ↳ Importance in Demography
  • ↳ Influencing Factors : Mortality differences between genders. Sex-selective migration. Sex ratio at birth.
  • ↳ Influencing Factors
  • ↳ Mortality differences between genders. Sex-selective migration. Sex ratio at birth.
  • ↳ Mortality differences between genders.
  • ↳ Sex-selective migration.
  • ↳ Sex ratio at birth.
  • ↳ Implications of Low Sex Ratio : Indicates a preference for male children. Results in gender inequities. This leads to neglect of girls, higher female mortality in youth, female infanticide, and foeticide. Increases maternal mortality. Bias towards males in population counts.
  • ↳ Implications of Low Sex Ratio
  • ↳ Indicates a preference for male children. Results in gender inequities. This leads to neglect of girls, higher female mortality in youth, female infanticide, and foeticide. Increases maternal mortality. Bias towards males in population counts.
  • ↳ Indicates a preference for male children.
  • ↳ Results in gender inequities.
  • ↳ This leads to neglect of girls, higher female mortality in youth, female infanticide, and foeticide.
  • ↳ Increases maternal mortality.
  • ↳ Bias towards males in population counts.
  • ↳ Males are less than 500 (Option A) : This is incorrect because the male population being so low would result in an extremely skewed sex ratio, which is unrealistic in this context.
  • ↳ Males are less than 500 (Option A)
  • ↳ Females are less than 500 (Option B) : This is incorrect because a sex ratio greater than 1000 implies there are more females, not fewer.
  • ↳ Females are less than 500 (Option B)
  • ↳ Females are less than 5000 (Option D) : This is incorrect because for the sex ratio to exceed 1000, the number of females must be more than 5000.
  • ↳ Females are less than 5000 (Option D)
    • References:

    • ↳ Female Deficit Syndrome

questions.text: The term demographic bonus is due to:
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Decline in dependency ratio

Demographic Gift

Demographic Liability

The demographic gift occurs when the working-age population is high relative to dependents.

The higher proportion of elderly individuals refers to demographic liability.

Represents a potential demographic dividend due to a larger workforce contributing to economic growth.

Represents potential economic challenges due to increased dependency ratios and healthcare costs

Contributors include higher productivity, increased savings, and economic growth

Dependents include retirees, elderly individuals, and those requiring significant healthcare

questions.text: What is the current ideal total fertility rate in India?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - 2.

questions.text: The average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the women in her age group is called as:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Total fertility

questions.text: What phase of the demographic cycle is the low stationary phase of demographic cycle?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Phase 4

Stages

Birth rate

Death rate

Population

I. High stationery (Option A)

 

High

High

Population is stable

II. Early expanding (Option B)

 

High

Starts declining

Population grows at faster rate . Also called demographic trap

III. Late expanding (Option C)

 

Starts declining

Keeps declining

Population grows at slower rate (birth > death)

IV. Low stationery

Low

Low

Stable population

V. Declining

Low

Lower

Population declines (death rate > birth rate)

questions.text: Which stage of the demographic cycle has the highest birth and death rates?
Infant mortality rate is typically stated as a rate per how many live births.?
Which of the following is the sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community?
questions.explanation:
Crude death rate

CDR = (Total no. or deaths in a community/ MYP (Mid-year population) in the same area) x 100

  • The mid-year population is taken on 1st July
  • Limitation: It does not consider the age and sex of the population

Age-specific death rate

ASDR = (Total no. of deaths in a particular age group (eg. 20-24yrs) a given area in a year/ MYP of the age group in the same area and year) x 1000

Expectation of life

 

 
  • Life expectancy at birth: A positive mortality indicator· Average no. of years a newborn is expected to live, considering the current age-specific mortality rates in a community.
  • Important component to calculate the Human Development Index (HDI).
  • Life expectancy at one year is PQLI. In 2021, life expectancy in India is 69.7 years.

Infant mortality rate

IMR = (Total number of deaths (0-1-year-old) in a given year / Total number of live births in the same year) x 1000. It is a health status indicator.

Under-five mortality rate

U5MR = (Total number of deaths (0-5 years old) in a given year /Total number of live births in one year) x 1000

Maternal Mortality Rate (Option B)

Maternal Mortality Rate (MMR) = (Total no. of maternal deaths/women in the reproductive age group [15-49 years]) x 100,000

Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR)

Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) = (Total no. of maternal deaths/Live Births) x 100,000

 

Adult mortality rate

Probability of dying between 15 to 60 years of life

Year of potential life lost

Premature death measurement. If life expectancy is 75 years, and death happens at age 30, then 45 years of potential life is lost

Proportional mortality rate

The simplest measure of the burden of disease (Total deaths due to disease 'x'/ Total deaths in a community)́ x 100

Case fatality rate

CFR = (Deaths due to diseases ‘z’ / total no of cases of disease ‘z’) x 100

Quality-adjusted Life Years (QALY)
  • Quality and quantity of life lived.
  • Assesses number of years of life added due to the intervention and hence the benefit and value for money of the intervention
  • QALY - 1 year of life lived in perfect health
  • Positive indicator of the cost-effectiveness of an intervention.
  • Scored between 0 (death) and 1 (perfect health).

Disability-adjusted Life Years (DALY)

(Option D)
  • DALY= Years of life lost to premature death + years lived with disability
  • 1 DALY: 1 year of healthy life lost
  • It is a measure of the burden of disease and the effectiveness of intervention
     

Year of life lost (YLL):

  • Calculated from the number of deaths at each age multiplied by the expected remaining years of life according to a global standard life expectancy.
     

Years lost to disability (YLD):

  • Where the number of incident cases due to injury and illness is multiplied by the average duration of the disease and a weighting factor reflecting the severity of the disease on a scale from 0 (perfect health) to 1 (dead).

 

DALY = YLL + YLD

Health Adjusted Life Expectancy (HALE)
  • The average number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health considering the current age-specific mortality rate.
    Healthy Life Expectancy
    • HALE = Life Expectancy at birth + adjustment of time spent in poor health
    • HALE = LE-DALY

Life Expectancy

  • Average no. of years a newborn is expected to live, considering the current age-specific mortality rate.

Sullivan’s index
(or DFLE)
  • Disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) with the current pattern of mortality and disability.

questions.explanation:
